Haarde]] speaks with reporters on 27 October 2008.]] {{History of Iceland}} The '''Icelandic financial crisis''' was a major [[financial crisis|economic]] and political event in [[Iceland]] that involved the [[default (finance)|default]] of all three of the country's major privately owned [[commercial bank]]s in late 2008, following their difficulties in [[refinancing]] their [[current liability|short-term debt]] and a [[bank run|run on deposits]] in the [[Netherlands]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. Relative to the size of its economy, Iceland's systemic banking collapse was the largest experienced by any country in economic history.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12762027|title=Cracks in the crust|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[The Economist]]|date=11 December 2008|accessdate=4 February 2013}}{{subscription}} The crisis led to a severe [[economic depression]] in 2008–2010 and [[2009 Icelandic financial crisis protests|significant political unrest]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2015/cr1573.pdf|title=Iceland. Selected issues.|publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]]|date=March 2015|accessdate=9 May 2015}} In the years preceding the crisis, three Icelandic banks, [[Kaupthing]], [[Landsbanki]] and [[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir]], multiplied in size. This expansion was driven by ready access to credit in international financial markets, in particular [[money market]]s. As the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]] unfolded, investors perceived the Icelandic banks to be increasingly risky. Trust in the banks gradually faded, leading to a sharp depreciation of the [[Icelandic króna]] in 2008 and increased difficulties for the banks in rolling over their short-term debt. At the end of the second quarter of 2008, Iceland's [[external debt]] was 9.553 trillion [[Icelandic krónur]] (€50 billion), more than 7 times the [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] of Iceland in 2007.{{Cite web|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/?pageid=552&itemid=a55be3a0-9943-484e-a8de-46d23f17ba25&nextday=4&nextmonth=12|publisher =[[Central Bank of Iceland]]|date = 4 September 2008|title = External debt|accessdate = 11 October 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081021220411/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?pageid=552&itemid=a55be3a0-9943-484e-a8de-46d23f17ba25&nextday=4&nextmonth=12|archivedate = 21 October 2008|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.statice.is/?PageID=444&newsid=2950&highlight=Gross%20Domestic%20Product%202007|website =Statistics Iceland|date = 11 September 2008|title = Gross domestic product 2007– Revision|accessdate = 13 October 2008}} The assets of the three banks totaled 14.437 trillion krónur at the end of the second quarter 2008,Glitnir ISK 3,863 bn {{Cite web |url=http://www.glitnirbank.com/servlet/file/2quarter_2008.pdf?ITEM_ENT_ID=11447&COLLSPEC_ENT_ID=156 |title=Interim Financial Statement 2008Q2 |publisher=[[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir]]|format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205091126/http://www.glitnirbank.com/servlet/file/2quarter_2008.pdf?ITEM_ENT_ID=11447&COLLSPEC_ENT_ID=156 |archivedate=5 February 2009 |url-status=dead |access-date=16 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}; Landsbanki ISK 3,970 bn {{cite web|url=http://www.landsbanki.is/Uploads/Documents/ArsskyrslurOgUppgjor/landsbanki_consolidated_interim_financial_statements_30-jun-2008.pdf|title=Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements:1 January - 30 June 2008|publisher=[[Landsbanki]]|access-date=November 7, 2019}}; Kaupthing ISK 6,604 bn {{cite web|url=http://www.kaupthing.com/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=17006|title=Interim Financial Statement 2008Q2|publisher=[[Kaupthing]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081114164038/http://www.kaupthing.com/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=17006|archivedate=November 14, 2008|date=November 14, 2008|url-status=dead|format=PDF}}. The borrowings of the three banks at the same date were: Glitnir ISK 2,242 bn; Landsbanki ISK 1,220 bn; Kaupthing ISK 2,883 bn. equal to more than 11 times the national GDP. Due to the huge size of the Icelandic financial system in comparison with the Icelandic economy, the [[Central Bank of Iceland]] found itself unable to act as a lender of last resort during the crisis, further aggravating the mistrust in the banking system. On 29 September 2008, it was announced that [[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir]] would be nationalised. However, subsequent efforts to restore faith in the banking system failed. On 6 October, the [[Althing|Icelandic legislature]] instituted an [[emergency law]] which enabled the [[Financial Supervisory Authority (Iceland)|Financial Supervisory Authority]] (FME) to take control over financial institutions and made domestic [[deposits]] in the banks priority claims. In the following days, new banks were founded to take over the domestic operations of Kaupthing, Landsbanki and Glitnir. The old banks were put into [[receivership]] and liquidation, resulting in losses for their [[shareholder]]s and foreign [[creditor]]s. Outside Iceland, more than half a million depositors lost access to their accounts in foreign branches of Icelandic banks. This led to the 2008–2013 [[Icesave dispute]], that ended with an [[EFTA Court]] ruling that Iceland was not obliged to repay Dutch and British depositors minimum [[deposit insurance|deposit guarantees]]. In an effort to stabilize the situation, the Icelandic government stated that all domestic deposits in Icelandic banks would be guaranteed, imposed strict [[capital controls]] to stabilize the value of the Icelandic króna, and secured a US$5.1bn sovereign debt package from the [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] and the [[Nordic countries]] in order to finance a [[budget deficit]] and the restoration of the banking system. The international bailout support programme led by IMF officially ended on 31 August 2011, while the capital controls which were imposed in November 2008 were lifted on 14 March 2017.{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/business/iceland-economy-finance-capital-controls.html?_r=0 | title=Iceland, Symbol of Financial Crisis, Finally Lifts Capital Controls| newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| date=March 14, 2017|access-date=November 7, 2019| last1=Alderman| first1=Liz}} The financial crisis had a serious negative impact on the [[Economy of Iceland|Icelandic economy]]. The national currency fell sharply in value, foreign currency transactions were virtually suspended for weeks, and the [[market capitalisation]] of the Icelandic stock exchange fell by more than 90%. As a result of the crisis, Iceland underwent a severe economic depression; the country's [[gross domestic product]] dropped by 10% in real terms between the third quarter of 2007 and the third quarter of 2010.{{Cite web|title = Seasonally adjusted quarterly volume growth in GDP 1980–2014|url = http://www.statice.is/?PageID=1267&src=https://rannsokn.hagstofa.is/pxen/Dialog/varval.asp?ma=THJ01703%26ti=Seasonally+adjusted+quarterly+volume+growth+in+GDP+1980-2014%26path=../Database/thjodhagsreikningar/landsframleidsla_althj/%26lang=1%26units=Percent|publisher = Statistics Iceland|accessdate = 9 May 2015}} A new era with positive GDP growth started in 2011, and has helped foster a gradually declining trend for the unemployment rate. The [[government budget deficit]] has declined from 9.7% of GDP in 2009 and 2010 to 0.2% of GDP in 2014;{{Cite web|title=Hagstofa Íslands. Helstu hagstærðir hins opinbera 1980–2014|url= http://hagstofa.is/?PageID=2602&src=https://rannsokn.hagstofa.is/pxis/Dialog/varval.asp?ma=THJ00511%26ti=Helstu+hagst%E6r%F0ir+hins+opinbera+1980%2D2014++++++++++%26path=../Database/thjodhagsreikningar/fjarmal_opinber/%26lang=3%26units=Millj%F3nir%20Kr%F3na/v%EDsitala/hluthlut|publisher=Statistics Iceland|language=is|accessdate=25 May 2015}} the central government gross [[debt-to-GDP ratio]] was expected to decline to less than 60% in 2018 from a maximum of 85% in 2011.{{Cite web|title=Stefna í lánamálum ríkisins 2015–2018.|url= http://www.fjarmalaraduneyti.is/media/frettatengt2015/Stefna_i_lanamalum_rikisins_2015-2018.pdf|publisher=[[Ministry of Finance (Iceland)]]|language=is|accessdate=25 May 2015}} ==Development== ===Currency=== [[File:ISK exchange rate Sep-Nov 2008.png|thumb|right|300px|The decline of the Icelandic króna against the euro, shown from September to November 2008. The lower solid line (in brown) shows the offshore rate as quoted by the European Central Bank; the higher solid line (in blue) shows the onshore rate as quoted by the Central Bank of Iceland. The two solid lines diverge on 6 October, after Glitnir had defaulted on some wholesale depositors in the UK, although there had been unusually large differences (up to 5%) during the previous week. The lower dashed line (in black) shows the average rate from January to August 2008 (113.31 krónur to the euro, already down from 91.2 krónur to the euro on 31 December 2007), while the upper dashed line shows the long term average from 1999 to 2007 (83.423 krónur to the euro).]] The Icelandic króna had declined more than 35% against the euro from January to September 2008.{{Cite 14%,{{Cite web|publisher = [[Central Bank of Iceland]]|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=6451|title = Economic Indicators |accessdate = 11 October 2008 |date= September 2008}} https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/financialcrisis/3273300/Iceland-raises-rates-to-18pc-as-part-of-IMFs-1bn-rescue.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|author = Mason, dmy-all}} During November, the real exchange rate (discounting inflation) of the Icelandic króna, as quoted by the Central Bank of Iceland, was roughly one-third lower than the average rate from 1980–2008, and 20% lower than the historical lows during the same period.{{Cite web|publisher=[[Central Bank of Iceland]]|title = Monetary policy statement of the Board of Governors of the Central Bank of Iceland: Of vital importance to stabilise the foreign exchange market and strengthen the króna|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1983|date = 28 November 2008|accessdate = 1 December 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220063647/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1983|archivedate = 20 December 2008|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} The external rate as quoted by the European Central Bank was lower still. On the last trading day of the month, 28 November, the Central Bank of Iceland was quoting 182.5 krónur to the euro, while the European Central Bank was quoting 280 krónur to the euro. On 28 November, the Central Bank of Iceland and the [[Minister for Business Affairs (Iceland)|Minister for Business Affairs]] agreed on a new set of currency regulations,{{cite web|url=http://www.sedlabanki.is/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=6631|title=Rules on foreign exchange No. 1082|publisher=[[Central Bank of Iceland]]|date=November 28, 2008|access-date=November 20, 2019}} replacing the central bank's restrictions imposed early on in the crisis.{{Cite web|publisher=[[Central Bank of Iceland]]|date = 28 November 2008|title = New foreign exchange regulation|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1980|accessdate = 4 December 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220063641/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1980|archivedate = 20 December 2008|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} Movements of capital to and from Iceland were banned without a license from central bank.{{Cite web|publisher=[[Central Bank of Iceland]]|date = 30 November 2008|title = Questions and answers about foreign exchange matters|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1985|accessdate = 4 December 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220063652/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1985|archivedate = 20 December 2008|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} It is estimated that foreign investors hold some €2.9 billion in króna-denominated securities, popularly known as "glacier bonds".{{citation|title = Floating kronur and flying eggs|url = http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2008/12/03/floating-kronur-and-flying-eggs/|date =December 3, 2008|website=[[IceNews]]|author=Alëx|access-date=November 20, 2019}} The foreign exchange rules also oblige Icelandic residents to deposit any new foreign currency they receive with an Icelandic bank. There is anecdotal evidence that some Icelandic exporters had been operating an informal offshore foreign exchange market,{{cite news|title = Grace under Fire... and Ice|url = http://www.icelandreview.com/icelandreview/daily_life/?cat_id=16571&ew_0_a_id=315319|date =November 13, 2008|website=[[Iceland Review]]|last=Moody|first=Jonas|url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131134155/http://www.icelandreview.com/icelandreview/daily_life/?cat_id=16571&ew_0_a_id=315319|archive-date=January 31, 2009}} trading pounds and euros for krónur outside the control of any regulator and starving the onshore market of foreign currency. Hence the Central Bank had to sell €124 million of currency reserves in November 2008 to make up the difference, compared with an estimated trade surplus of €13.9 million.{{Cite web|author = Statistics Iceland|title = External trade, preliminary figures for November 2008|url = http://www.statice.is/Pages/444?NewsID=2895|date = 3 December 2008|accessdate = 5 December 2008|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130521220650/http://www.statice.is/Pages/444?NewsID=2895|archive-date = 21 May 2013|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} The last currency auction was held on 3 December. The domestic [[interbank foreign exchange market]] reopened the following day with three [[market maker]]s, all of them government-owned.{{Cite web|title = Interbank foreign exchange market|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1988|publisher =[[Central Bank of Iceland]]|date = 3 December 2008|accessdate = 4 December 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220064051/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?PageID=287&NewsID=1988|archivedate = 20 December 2008|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} On the first two days of domestic trading, the króna climbed to 153.3 to the euro, up 22% against the last currency auction rate.{{citation needed|date=November 2019}} In January 2009, the exchange rate of Icelandic króna against Euro seemed to be more stabilized compared with the situation in October 2008, with the lowest rate at 177.5 krónur per EUR on 1, 3 and 4 January 2009, and the highest at 146.8 on 30 January 2009.{{cite news|title = Iceland interest rates unchanged|work=[[BBC News]]|date = 29 January 2009|accessdate = 8 March 2009|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7857743.stm|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090201145034/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7857743.stm|archivedate= 1 February 2009 |url-status= live}} In the meantime, however, Iceland's 12-month inflation in January 2009 climbed to a record high of 18.6%.{{Cite web |title=Iceland's inflation hits record 18.6 percent in Jan |publisher=FreshPlaza |accessdate=8 March 2009 |url=http://www.freshplaza.com/news_detail.asp?id=37630 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hLPaEY7a?url=http://www.freshplaza.com/news_detail.asp?id=37630 |archivedate=7 June 2009 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }} ===Banks=== In September 2008, internal documents from [[Kaupthing]], the largest bank in Iceland, were leaked to [[WikiLeaks]].{{cite journal|last1=Moody|first1=Jonas|title=Report Questions Lending of Iceland Bank|journal=Time|date=10 August 2009}} On 29 September 2008, a plan was announced for the bank [[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir]] to be nationalised by the Icelandic government with the purchase of a 75% stake for €600 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.glitnir.is/english/about-glitnir/news/detail/item14983/The_government_of_Iceland_acquires_75_percent_share_in_Glitnir_Bank/|author=Glitnir|title=The government of Iceland acquires 75 percent share in Glitnir Bank|date=29 September 2008|accessdate=30 September 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081002023742/http://www.glitnir.is/english/about-glitnir/news/detail/item14983/The_government_of_Iceland_acquires_75_percent_share_in_Glitnir_Bank/|archivedate= 2 October 2008|url-status= dead}}{{Cite web|url=http://eng.forsaetisraduneyti.is/news-and-articles/nr/3016|author=Prime Minister's Office|title= The Government of Iceland provides Glitnir with new equity|date=29 September 2008|accessdate=30 September 2008}} The government stated that it did not intend to hold ownership of the bank for a long period, and that the bank was expected to carry on operating as normal. According to the government, the bank "would have ceased to exist" within a few weeks if there had not been intervention.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7641753.stm|title=Iceland nationalises Glitnir bank|work=BBC News|date=29 September 2008|accessdate=30 September 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081221113845/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7641753.stm|archivedate=21 December 2008 |url-status= live}} It later turned out that Glitnir had US$750 million of debt due to mature on 15 October.{{cite news|author = Sherwood, Joel|work=Wall Street Journal|title = Iceland Seen Turning to IMF|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122425739356744673?mod=sphere_ts&mod=sphere_wd|date = 17 October 2008|accessdate = 18 October 2008}} However, the nationalization of Glitnir never went through, as it was placed in [[receivership]] by the FME before the initial plan of the Icelandic government to purchase a 75% stake had been approved by shareholders. The announced nationalisation of Glitnir came just as the United Kingdom government was forced to nationalise [[Bradford & Bingley]] and to sell its retail operations and branch network to [[Grupo Santander]]. Over the weekend of 4–5 October, British newspapers carried many articles detailing the nationalisation of Glitnir and the high [[leverage (finance)|leverage]] of Iceland's other banks.{{cite news|work=The Sunday Times|location=London|author = Goodman, Matthew|url = http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article4881378.ece|title = An icy blast cuts deep into Iceland|date = 5 October 2008|accessdate = 16 October 2008 }} Influential [[BBC]] business editor [[Robert Peston]] published an opinion piece on the banks, stating that debt insurance for Kaupthing required a premium of £625,000 to guarantee the return of £1 million: "the worst case of financial [[body odor|BO]] I've encountered in some time" was his graphic description.{{cite news|work=BBC News|author = Peston, Robert|authorlink = Robert Peston|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/robertpeston/2008/10/creditors_call_time_on_iceland.html|title = Markets call time on Iceland|date = 4 October 2008|accessdate = 16 October 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081007065042/http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/thereporters/robertpeston/2008/10/creditors_call_time_on_iceland.html|archivedate= 7 October 2008 |url-status= live}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' said "Iceland is on the brink of collapse. Inflation and interest rates are raging upwards. The krona, Iceland's currency, is in freefall."{{cite news|work=The Guardian|location=London|author = McVeigh, Tracy|url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/oct/05/iceland.creditcrunch|title = The party's over for Iceland, the island that tried to buy the world|date = 5 October 2008|accessdate = 16 October 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081016054307/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/oct/05/iceland.creditcrunch|archivedate= 16 October 2008 |url-status= live}} These articles spooked investors discussing Icesave (the brand name of Landsbanki in the UK and the Netherlands) in online forums and many started moving their savings out of the Internet bank.{{Cite web|title = How Long Can Icelandic Banks Last?, Will all Icelanders go bankrupt?|url = http://www.housepricecrash.co.uk/forum/index.php?showtopic=89949|publisher = [[HousePriceCrash]] Forums|date = 4–5 October 2008|accessdate = 16 October 2008}} Problems with access to the site hinted at a run on savings. On 6 October, a number of [[interbank lending market|private interbank credit facilities]] to Icelandic banks were shut down.{{Cite web|title = Address to the Nation by H.E. Geir H. Haarde, Prime Minister of Iceland|url = http://eng.forsaetisraduneyti.is/news-and-articles/nr/3035|date = 6 October 2008|accessdate = 17 October 2008|publisher = Prime Minister's Office}} Prime Minister [[Geir Haarde]] addressed the nation in a speech that became infamous for its portentous closing words: '[[God bless Iceland]]'. He announced a package of new regulatory measures which were to be put to the [[Althing]], Iceland's parliament, immediately, with the cooperation of the opposition parties. This reflects the fact that the value of the three big banks, which form 73.2% of the value of the OMX Iceland 15,{{Cite web|author = OMX Nordic Exchange|url = https://newsclient.omxgroup.com/cds/DisclosureAttachmentServlet?messageAttachmentId=190910|title = Definitive list of constituents in OMXI15 index|date = 30 June 2008|accessdate= 25 March 2010 }} had been set to zero.{{Cite web|url = http://www.omxnordicexchange.com/|title = Equities resume trading in Iceland|author = OMX Nordic Exchange|accessdate = 14 October 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081009131035/http://www.omxnordicexchange.com/|archivedate= 9 October 2008 |url-status= live}} The values of other equities varied from +8% to −15%.{{cite news|title = Stock exchange update|url = http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2008/10/14/stock-exchange-update/|date = 14 October 2008|newspaper = IceNews|accessdate = 15 October 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081016083028/http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2008/10/14/stock-exchange-update/|archivedate= 16 October 2008 |url-status= live}} Trading in shares of [[Exista]], [[SPRON]] and [[Straumur-Burðarás]] (13.66% of the OMX Iceland 15) remains suspended. After a week of very thin trading, the OMX Iceland 15 closed on 17 October at 643.1, down 93% in króna terms and 96% in euro terms from its historic high of 9016 (18 July 2007). Trading in the shares of two financial services companies, Straumur–Burðarás and Exista, resumed on 9 December: together the companies account for 12.04% of the OMX Iceland 15. The values of the shares in both companies dropped sharply, and the index closed at 394.88, down by 40.17% on the day. Trading in shares in SPRON and Kaupthing remains suspended, at prices of 1.90 krónur and 694.00 krónur respectively.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasdaqomxnordic.com/indexes/index_info/?Instrument=ICEIS0000004380|title=Index info|publisher=Nasdaqomxnordic.com|accessdate=11 November 2009}} ===Sovereign debt=== {|class="wikitable" style="float:left; width:30%;" |+ Ratings of Icelandic sovereign debt

However the agencies believed that the government would have to issue more foreign currency bonds, both to cover losses as the banks' overseas operations are liquidation and also to stimulate demand in the domestic economy as Iceland goes into recession.{{Cite web|author = Moody's|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=6483|title = Moody's downgrades Iceland's ratings to A1 from Aa1; review continues|date = 8 October 2008|accessdate = 11 October 2008}} A team of experts from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) arrived in Iceland at the start of October 2008 for talks with the government. We are working thoroughly on the issue to take a final decision".{{cite news|date = 15 October 2008|author1=Lannin, Patrick |author2=Valdimarsson, Omar |title = Iceland slashes rates, Russia studies loan request|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/bondsNews/idUSLF14318220081015?sp=true|work = Reuters|accessdate = 15 October 2008}} On the same day, the Central Bank of Iceland drew on its [[Currency swap|swap facilities]] with the central banks of Denmark and Norway for €200 million each. Iceland has swap facilities with the other Nordic countries for a total of €1.5 billion.{{Cite web|author = Central Bank of Iceland|url = http://www.omxnordicexchange.com/newsandstatistics/companynotices/IFrameCNSMessage//?node=https%3A//newsclient.omxgroup.com/cdsPublic/viewDisclosure.action%3FdisclosureId%3D293561%26messageId%3D346338|title = The Central Bank of Iceland draws on swap facility arrangements|date = 14 October 2008|accessdate = 15 October 2008}} Iceland is also seeking assistance from the European Central Bank (ECB): there is some precedent for the move, as the ECB already has currency swap arrangements with Switzerland, another non-member of the [[European Union]].{{cite news|publisher = Bloomberg|date = 16 October 2008|accessdate = 18 October 2008|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ahVJCzeiIPhs|title = ECB Power Grows Beyond Borders as Neighbors Seek Aid|author = Kennedy, Simon}} On 24 October, the IMF tentatively agreed to lend €1.58 billion.{{cite news|url=http://www.iceland.org/info/iceland-imf-program/ |title=Iceland set for $2.1bn IMF help |publisher=Icelandic Government |date=19 October 2008 |accessdate=24 October 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131060539/http://www.iceland.org/info/iceland-imf-program/ |archivedate=31 January 2009 }}
{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7689633.stm|title=Iceland set for $2.1bn IMF help|work= BBC.co.uk|date=19 October 2008|accessdate=4 February 2013}} However the loan had still not been approved by the Executive Board of the IMF on 13 November.{{Cite web|title = Transcript of Regular Press Briefing by David Hawley, Senior Advisor, External Relations Department|publisher = International Monetary Fund|date = 13 November 2008|url = http://www.imf.org/external/np/tr/2008/tr111308.htm|accessdate = 15 November 2008}} Due to the delay Iceland found itself caught in a classic catch-22 situation, loans from other countries could not be secured until the IMF program had been approved. December 2008 |url-status= live}} ==Causes== [[File:Arsbreytinglandsfr2000-8 English.png|300px|thumb|Economic growth in Iceland, Denmark, Norway and Sweden from 2000 to 2007. Iceland is in red.]] In 2001, banks were deregulated in Iceland.{{cite journal|journal=[[Financial Times]]|author=Robert Jackson|title=The Big Chill|date=15 November 2008}} This set the stage for banks to upload debts when foreign companies were accumulated. The crisis unfolded when banks became unable to [[refinance]] their debts. It is estimated that the three major banks held [[foreign debt]] in excess of €50 billion, or about €160,000 per Icelandic resident, compared with Iceland's gross domestic product of €8.5 billion.For the purposes of comparison, both the external debt of Icelandic banks and the Icelandic GDP have been converted at an approximate exchange rate of ISK 150 = 1 EUR. As early as March 2008, the cost of private deposit insurance for deposits in Landsbanki and Kaupthing was already far higher (6–8½% of the sum deposited) than for other European banks.{{cite news|author = Watkins, Simon|date = 16 March 2008|title = Iceland's banks top 'riskiness league'|url = http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/investing-and-markets/article.html?in_article_id=433257&in_page_id=3|publisher = ThisIsMoney.co.uk|accessdate = 12 October 2008}} The króna, which was ranked by ''[[The Economist]]'' in early 2007 as the most overvalued currency in the world (based on the [[Big Mac Index]]),{{cite news|title = The Big Mac index|work=The Economist|accessdate = 11 October 2008|date = 1 February 2007|url = http://www.economist.com/markets/indicators/displaystory.cfm?story_id=8649005|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080930005545/http://www.economist.com/markets/indicators/displaystory.cfm?story_id=8649005|archivedate= 30 September 2008 |url-status= live}} has further suffered from the effects of [[Carry trade#Currency|carry trading]].{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20081007/ap_on_re_eu/eu_iceland_meltdown |author=Wardell, Jane |title=Iceland teeters on the brink of bankruptcy |agency=Associated Press |date=7 October 2008 |accessdate=8 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011122649/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20081007/ap_on_re_eu/eu_iceland_meltdown |archivedate=11 October 2008 |url-status=live |df=dmy }} Coming from a small domestic market, Iceland's banks have [[corporate finance|financed]] their expansion with loans on the [[interbank lending market]] and, more recently, by [[deposit account|deposits]] from outside Iceland (which are also a form of external debt). Households also took on a large amount of debt, equivalent to 213% of [[disposable income]], which led to inflation.{{cite news|title = Kreppanomics|work=The Economist|date = 9 October 2008|accessdate = 10 October 2008|url = http://www.economist.com/finance/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12382011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081012020021/http://www.economist.com/finance/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12382011|archivedate= 12 October 2008 |url-status= live}} This inflation was exacerbated by the practice of the Central Bank of Iceland issuing liquidity loans to banks on the basis of newly issued, uncovered bondsPara. 19, [http://www.forsaetisraduneyti.is/media/Skyrslur/LOI.pdf "Letter of Intent to the International Monetary Fund"] (PDF). 3 November 2008. – effectively, printing money on demand. In response to the rise in prices – 14% in the twelve months to September 2008, compared with a target of 2.5% – the Central Bank of Iceland held [[interest rate]]s high (15.5%). Such high interest rates, compared with 5.5% in the United Kingdom or 4% in the [[eurozone]] for example, encouraged overseas investors to hold deposits in Icelandic krónur, leading to [[monetary inflation]]: the Icelandic [[money supply]] (M3) grew 56.5% in the twelve months to September 2008, compared with 5.0% GDP growth.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sedlabanki.is/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=6628|title=Economic Indicators|format=PDF|publisher= Central Bank of Iceland|website=|date=November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101218013836/http://sedlabanki.is/lisalib/getfile.aspx?itemid=6628|archivedate=18 December 2010|accessdate= 4 February 2013}} GDP growth is for the second quarter 2008 (annualised); Q3 growth was −0.8% (annualised). The situation was effectively an [[economic bubble]], with investors overestimating the true value of the króna. As with many banks around the world, the Icelandic banks found it increasingly difficult or impossible to roll over their loans in the [[interbank market]], their creditors insisting on payment while no other banks were willing to make fresh loans. In such a situation, a bank would normally have to ask for a loan from the [[central bank]] as the [[lender of last resort]]. However, in Iceland the banks were so much larger than the national economy that the Central Bank of Iceland and the Icelandic government could not guarantee the payment of the banks' debts, leading to the collapse of the banks.{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7852275.stm |title = Waking up to reality in Iceland |work = BBC News |accessdate = 27 January 2009 |date=26 January 2009|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090126205753/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7852275.stm|archivedate= 26 January 2009 |url-status= live}} The official reserves of the Central Bank of Iceland stood at 374.8 billion krónur at the end of September 2008,{{Cite web|author = Central Bank of Iceland|url = http://www.sedlabanki.is/?pageid=552&itemid=29d909f3-c66a-41a3-bc6c-dadb8cac486f&nextday=7&nextmonth=11|title = International reserves and foreign currency liquidity – September 2008|date = 7 October 2008|accessdate = 11 October 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081010223028/http://www.sedlabanki.is/?pageid=552&itemid=29d909f3-c66a-41a3-bc6c-dadb8cac486f&nextday=7&nextmonth=11|archivedate = 10 October 2008|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}} compared with 350.3 billion krónur of short-term international debt in the Icelandic banking sector, and at least £6.5 billion (1,250 billion krónur) of retail deposits in the UK.Calculated as £4 billion in Icesave deposits and £2.5 billion in deposits at Heritable Bank and Kaupthing Singer & Friedlander that were handed to ING Direct. [[File:Icesave.png|thumb|The Icesave logo, advertising it as "part of Landsbanki, Reykjavík, Iceland"]] The situation was made worse by the fact that Icesave was operating as a branch of Landsbanki, rather than as a legally independent subsidiary. As such, it was completely dependent on the Central Bank of Iceland for emergency loans of [[liquidity]], and could not turn to the Bank of England for help. The UK Financial Services Authority (FSA) was aware of the risk, and was considering imposing special liquidity requirements on Icelandic deposit-taking banks in the weeks before the crisis.{{cite news|title = Lawyers head to Iceland to get cash back|work=The Independent|location=London|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/lawyers-head-to-iceland-to-get-cash-back-958345.html|author1=Leftly, Mark |author2=Northedge, Richard |date = 12 October 2008|accessdate = 15 October 2008 }} However the plan – which was never implemented – would have forced the Icelandic banks to cut interest rates or stop taking new deposits, and might even have sparked the sort of bank run it was designed to prevent. The Guernsey authorities were also planning on bringing in restrictions on foreign banks operating as branches and on transfers of funds between Guernsey subsidiaries and parent banks ("parental upstreaming").{{Cite web|author = Guernsey Financial Services Commission|title = Consultation on Parental Upstreaming and the Introduction of Depositor Protection and Ombudsman Schemes|url = https://www.gfsc.gg/UserFiles/File/Banking/Consultation_on_Parental_Upstreaming_and_the_Introduction_of_Depositor_Protection_and_Ombudsman_Schemes.pdf|accessdate = 15 October 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081029195833/https://www.gfsc.gg/UserFiles/File/Banking/Consultation_on_Parental_Upstreaming_and_the_Introduction_of_Depositor_Protection_and_Ombudsman_Schemes.pdf|archivedate = 29 October 2008|url-status = dead|date = August 2008|df = dmy-all}} Landsbanki operated in Guernsey through a legally independent subsidiary. The existence of a bank run on Landsbanki accounts in the UK in the period up to 7 October seems confirmed by a statement from the bank on 10 October, which said "Landsbanki Íslands hf. transferred substantial funds to its UK branch during this time to fulfil its Icesave commitments."{{Cite web|title = Statement from Landsbanki Íslands hf: Landsbanki did not transfer funds from the UK to Iceland|author = Landsbanki Íslands hf|date = 10 October 2008|url = http://www.landsbanki.is/english/aboutlandsbanki/pressreleases/?GroupID=720&NewsID=13336&y=0&p=1|archive-url = http://wayback.vefsafn.is/wayback/20081114214700/http://www.landsbanki.is/english/aboutlandsbanki/pressreleases/?GroupID=720&NewsID=13336&y=0&p=1|url-status = dead|archive-date = 14 November 2008|accessdate = 15 October 2008}} The transfer of funds from Landsbanki Guernsey to [[Heritable Bank]], a Landsbanki subsidiary in the UK, also suggests a bank run in the UK. A transfer of "substantial funds" from Iceland to the UK would have been a significant downward push on the value of the króna, even before the effects of any speculation. ==Bank restructuring== Wholesale funding disappeared in September 2008 leading to the collapse of Glitnir, Kaupthing and Landsbanki. Due to the size of the combined balance sheet of those banks the government of Iceland did not have the means to save those banks. They were put into receivership instead with their boards replaced. Nevertheless, the failed banks were restructured by dividing them into a new and an old bank in order to avoid a [[credit crunch]].[[BRUEGEL]] policy contribution Dezember 2011, Zsolt Darvas, ''A Tale of Three Countries: Recovery after Banking Crises'', p. 6-7 The new state-owned banks took over the domestic activities and have been recapitalised by government with a [[Tier 1 capital#Tier 1 capital ratio|capital ratio]] of 16% of all assets. Jón Ásgeir, who had been known as the "popstar businessman" due to his shaggy golden mullet, has become the subject of a satirical video on YouTube set to the theme of the movie ''[[The Godfather]]''. In addition, a former mistress later revealed details of his "playboy lifestyle" during a trial that found him guilty of false accounting (which prompted the Baugur Group to relocate to the United Kingdom). *[[Lýður Guðmundsson]] and Águst Guðmundsson,The Águst Guðmundsson involved here should not be confused with [[Águst Guðmundsson]], who is a famous Icelandic filmmaker of the same name. the frozen food entrepreneurs who were in charge of Kaupthing. *[[Björgólfur Thor Björgólfsson]] and [[Björgólfur Guðmundsson]], the shipping and brewing moguls who owned Landsbanki.Mason, Rowena (19 October 2008). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/financialcrisis/3227409/Iceland-falls-out-of-love-with-its-billionaires-financial-crisis.html "Iceland falls out of love with its billionaires"]. ''The Telegraph''. Reportedly, all of those under scrutiny are now rarely seen in public and some have apparently left the country. They are also reportedly the subjects of an ongoing investigation to determine if any of their business practices warrant criminal prosecution. ==Statements from former politicians== Former Prime Minister Davíð Oddsson has claimed that Iceland needs to investigate "unusual and unconventional loans" given by the banks to senior politicians during the years before the crisis. [[Björn Bjarnson]], the former Minister for Justice and Ecclesiastical Affairs, has started a blog detailing the problems with the business sector and the efforts to cover them up. This was cited as an example of how politicians and businessmen, who traditionally held a tight grip over the Icelandic media, have lost this control and that dozens of similar blogs have been created. Björn stated that:
“I have written a lot about problems in the business sector over the last 14 years, and I can only compare some parts of it to Enron. Here companies have been playing a game, using the media and publishing to make themselves look good. We only hope that the foreign media will soon begin to understand what has been going on.”
==Political aftermath== {{See also|Kitchenware Revolution}} [[File:Mótmælendur við Alþingishúsið.jpg|thumb|right|Some of the 6000 protesters in front of the ''Alþingishús'', seat of the Icelandic parliament, on 15 November 2008.]] Parts of the Icelandic public have arranged protests against the Central Bank, the [[Althingi|Parliament]] and the government's alleged lack of responsibility before and after the crisis, attracting between 3000 and 6000 people (1–2% of Iceland's population) on Saturdays.{{cite news|title = Icelanders Take to Streets to Protest Policy Makers' Failures. On January the third, the thirteenth consecutive protest was held. The protest bringing from 4000–7000 demonstrators(facts vary).|author1=Einarsdottir, Helga Kristin |author2=Brogger, Tasneem |url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=a0r9Lfo7mSUw&refer=europe|publisher = Bloomberg|date = 15 November 2008|accessdate = 15 November 2008}} In early November 2008, the [[President of Iceland]], [[Ólafur Ragnar Grímsson]], at an informal lunch with foreign diplomats, criticized Iceland's traditional friends (particularly Britain, Sweden and Denmark) as well as the International Monetary Fund. According to a memo from the Norwegian embassy, he suggested that the Russians might want to use the [[Keflavík Air Base]], the Russian ambassador replied that they had no need for it. The President is quoted to have said that Iceland would soon recover, even if they had to fight alone. The President does not necessarily agree with the government on these issues.{{cite news|author = Skjeseth, Alf|url = http://klassekampen.no/55221/article/item/null|title = Inviterer Russland|publisher = Klassekampen|date = 12 November 2008|accessdate = 13 November 2008|language = no|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090104171235/http://klassekampen.no/55221/article/item/null|archive-date = 4 January 2009|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}}{{cite news|url = http://politiken.dk/newsinenglish/article596825.ece|title = Iceland: Denmark has turned its back|newspaper = Politiken|date = 12 November 2008|accessdate = 13 November 2008}} In October 2008, the UK PM [[Gordon Brown]] used provisions in part 2 of the [[Anti-Terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001]] to freeze Landsbanki holdings in the United Kingdom.[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1855901,00.html "Iceland to Britain: 'We're No Terrorists'"]. "Time". 3 November 2008. Iceland's prime minister Geir Haarde protested against what he described as "a terrorist law being applied against us", calling it "a completely unfriendly act".[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/who-are-you-calling-terrorists-mr-brown-971471.html "Who are you calling terrorists, Mr Brown?"]. ''The Independent''. 24 October 2008[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4916933.ece "Relations in deep freeze as Iceland denounces UK’s ‘unfriendly’ action"]. ''The Times''. 10 October 2008 Angered by the British decision, Iceland decided to submit a formal complaint to [[NATO]] about their move, and it also provoked more than 80,000 Icelanders (equal to 25% of its entire population) to sign an online petition set up under the heading "Icelanders are not terrorists". The relationship got even tenser when UK replied a month later by cancelling its scheduled patrol of the Icelandic airspace in December 2008. Iceland has no [[Military of Iceland|standing army]] of its own, and relies on a long-term standing agreement with NATO where a group of member states have committed in turns to defend the Icelandic airspace, and the UK [[Royal Air Force]] had now cancelled this after mutual agreement with NATO (presumably with another member state having accepted the responsibility).{{cite news|url = http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-11-14-727094515_x.htm|title = British air force mission to Iceland scrapped|work=USA Today|date = 14 November 2008|accessdate = 15 November 2008}} According to a poll from late November 2008, 64% were in favour of early elections, with only 29.3% opposed.{{Cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90853/6540625.html|title=Poll: Majority of Icelanders want early elections – People's Daily Online|work=People's Daily|date=26 November 2008|accessdate=11 November 2009}} In a poll from 22 November 2008, the Social Democratic Alliance led with 33.6%, followed by the Left-Green Alliance at 27.8% and the Independence Party at 24.8%; the Progressive Party and the Liberal Party were far behind, with only 6.3% and 4.3%, respectively.{{Cite web|url=http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/32339/social_alliance_leads_rivals_in_iceland|title=Social Alliance Leads Rivals in Iceland: Angus Reid Global Monitor|publisher=Angus-reid.com|accessdate=11 November 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227043049/http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/32339/social_alliance_leads_rivals_in_iceland|archive-date=27 December 2008|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}} As the Parliament met again on 20 January 2009, there were [[2009 Icelandic financial crisis protests|protests]] with reinvigorated force and escalation of conflict between protesters and the police. On 22 January, police used tear gas to disperse people on [[Austurvöllur]] (the square in front of the Alþing), the first such use since the [[1949 anti-NATO riot in Iceland|1949 anti-NATO protest]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.mbl.is/mm/frettir/innlent/2009/01/22/taragasi_beitt_a_austurvelli/|title=Táragasi beitt á Austurvelli|publisher=mbl.is|accessdate=11 November 2009}} ===Government resignation=== Prime Minister [[Geir H. Haarde]] announced on 23 January 2009 that he would be stepping down as leader of the [[Independence Party (Iceland)|Independence Party]] for health reasons: he has been diagnosed as having a [[Esophageal cancer|malignant oesophageal tumour]]. He said he would travel to the Netherlands around the end of January for treatment. [[Minister of Education, Science and Culture (Iceland)|Education Minister]] and Independence Party vice-chairman [[Þorgerður Katrín Gunnarsdóttir]] was to serve as Prime Minister in his absence. The leader of the [[Social Democratic Alliance]], [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Iceland)|Foreign Minister]] [[Ingibjörg Sólrún Gísladóttir]], was also unwell, undergoing treatment for a [[benign tumor|benign]] brain tumour since September 2008. The government recommended that elections be held on 9 May 2009.{{citation|title = PM of Iceland steps down, elections to take place in May|url = http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2009/01/23/pm-of-iceland-steps-down-elections-to-take-place-in-may/#more-5432|publisher = IceNews|date = 23 January 2008|accessdate = 23 January 2008}} [[Björgvin G. Sigurðsson]], Iceland's [[Minister of Business Affairs (Iceland)|Commerce Minister]], resigned on 25 January, citing the pressures of the nation's economic collapse, as the country's political leaders failed to agree on how to lead country out of its financial crisis. One of his last acts as minister was to dismiss the director of the [[Financial Supervisory Authority (Iceland)|Financial Supervisory Authority]] (FSA). Björgvin acknowledged that Icelanders have lost faith in their government and political system. "I want to shoulder my part of the responsibility for that," he said.{{cite news|title = Iceland's commerce minister quits, citing meltdown|url = http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2009/jan/25/eu-iceland-elections-012509/?ap|agency = Associated Press|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date = 25 January 2009|accessdate = 4 February 2013}} Negotiations on continuing the coalition broke down the next day, apparently over demands from the Social Democratic Alliance to take over the leadership of the government, and Geir Haarde tendered the government's resignation to the President of Iceland, Ólafur Ragnar Grímsson.{{citation|title = Prime Minister Formally Tenders Government's Resignation|url = http://eng.forsaetisraduneyti.is/news-and-articles/nr/3348|publisher = Prime Minister's Office|location=Iceland|date = 26 January 2009|accessdate= 25 March 2010 }} The President asked the present government to continue until a new government can be formed,{{citation|title = Iceland's coalition government resigns|url = http://eng.utanrikisraduneyti.is/speeches-and-articles/nr/4746|publisher = Ministry of Foreign Affairs|date = 26 January 2009|accessdate= 25 March 2010 }} and held talks with the five political parties represented in the Althing.{{citation|title = Iceland's 'figurehead' president has important decision to make|url = http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2009/01/26/icelands-figurehead-president-has-important-decision-to-make/|publisher = IceNews|date = 26 January 2009|accessdate = 26 January 2009|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090131213809/http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2009/01/26/icelands-figurehead-president-has-important-decision-to-make/|archivedate= 31 January 2009 |url-status= live}} After these discussions, Ingibjörg Sólrún Gísladóttir of the Social Democratic Alliance and [[Steingrímur J. Sigfússon]] of the [[Left-Green Movement]] were asked by the President to negotiate the formation of a new coalition government. Such a coalition would be five seats short of an overall majority in the Althing, but the [[Progressive Party (Iceland)|Progressive Party]] (seven seats) was expected to support the coalition without actually joining the government.{{citation|title = New Icelandic government under negotiation|url = http://www.icenews.is/index.php/2009/01/27/new-icelandic-government-being-negotiated/|publisher = IceNews|date = 27 January 2009|accessdate= 25 March 2010 }} Neither party leader became Prime Minister: instead, the position went to Jóhanna Sigurðardóttir of the Social Democratic Alliance, then the [[Minister of Social Affairs and Social Security (Iceland)|Minister of Social Affairs and Social Security]],{{citation|title = Sigurdardóttir Ready to Become Iceland's PM|url = http://www.icelandreview.com/icelandreview/daily_news/?cat_id=16567&ew_0_a_id=319005|publisher = Iceland Review|date = 27 January 2009|accessdate= 25 March 2010 }} who became the new chairwoman of her party on 28 March 2009. BBC News. 23 April 2012. ==Crisis resolution== ===Recovery starting in 2011=== Iceland's financial position has steadily improved since the crash. The economic contraction and rise in unemployment appear to have been arrested by late 2010 and with growth under way in mid-2011.[http://www.oecd.org/document/16/0,3746,en_2649_201185_43946384_1_1_1_1,00.html "OECD Economic Surveys – Iceland, June 2011"]. oecd.org. Three main factors have been important in this regard. First is the emergency legislation passed by the Icelandic parliament in October 2008. It served to minimise the impact of the [[Financial crisis of 2007-2008#Week of 5 October 2008|financial crisis]] on the country. The Financial Supervisory Authority of Iceland used permission granted by the emergency legislation to take over the domestic operations of the three largest banks.{{Cite web|url=http://e24.no/spesial/finanskrisen/article2696518.ece |title=Gud velsigne Island!( Finanskrisen, Makro og politkk, Utenriks ) |publisher=E24.no |date=6 October 2008 |accessdate=8 July 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120702211413/http://e24.no/spesial/finanskrisen/article2696518.ece |archivedate=2 July 2012 |df=dmy }} The much larger foreign operations of the banks, however, went into receivership. A second important factor is the success of the IMF [[Stand-By-Arrangement]] in the country since November 2008. The SBA includes three pillars. The first pillar is a program of medium term fiscal consolidation, involving painful austerity measures and significant tax hikes. The result has been that central government debts have been stabilised at around 80–90 percent of GDP. A second pillar is the resurrection of a viable but sharply downsized domestic banking system on the ruins of its gargantuan international banking system which the government was unable to bail out. A third pillar is the enactment of capital controls and the work to gradually lift these to restore normal financial linkages with the outside world. An important result of the emergency legislation and the SBA is that the country has not been seriously affected by the [[European sovereign debt crisis]] from 2010. Despite a contentious debate with Britain and the Netherlands over the question of a state guarantee on the Icesave deposits of Landsbanki in these countries, [[credit default swaps]] on Icelandic sovereign debt have steadily declined from over 1000 points prior to the crash in 2008 to around 200 points in June 2011. The fact that the assets of the failed Landsbanki branches were estimated to cover most of the depositor claims had an influence to ease concerns over the situation. Finally, the third major factor behind the resolution of the financial crisis was the decision by the government of Iceland to apply for membership in the EU in July 2009. While views on the feasibility of EU membership are quite mixed in Iceland, this action has served to enhance the credibility of the country on international financial markets. One sign of the success of the above efforts is the fact that the Icelandic government was successfully able to raise $1 billion with a bond issue on 9 June 2011. This development indicates that international investors have given the government and the new banking system, with two of the three biggest banks now in foreign hands, a clean bill of health.{{Cite web|url=http://www.institutionalinvestor.com/Article/2845172/Iceland-To-Raise-1B-In-Bond-Sale.html?ArticleId=2845172|title=Iceland To Raise $1B in Bond Sale|work=Institutional Investor|accessdate=17 June 2011|date=9 June 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304319804576387572241329838?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Iceland's Banks Come in From the Cold|author=Asgeir Jonsson|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=17 June 2011|date=16 June 2011}} The first two major measures were implemented by the government of [[Geir H. Haarde]] but also carried out by the government of Johanna Sigurdardottir, which then took the step to apply for EU membership. Iceland has undertaken recapitalization of lenders such as injection of ISK 33 billion (2.1% of 2010 GDP) into [[Housing Financing Fund]] at the end of 2010, under a restructuring plan approved by the [[European Free Trade Association Surveillance Authority|EFTSA]].OECD Economic Surveys: Iceland 2011 -OECD – 2011 Page 50 "The Housing Finance Fund (cont.).. The increasing difficulties that many households have had in paying their mortgages since the financial crisis struck have necessitated substantial debt restructuring, eroding the HFF's capital. Including debt write-downs associated with the December 2010 agreement between the government and the main mortgage loan providers to reduce the value of certain mortgages to 110% of the value of the underlying property, impaired loans soared from ISK 3.4 billion (0.4% of the HFF's loan portfolio) in 2009 to ISK 38.8 billion (5.2% of the loan portfolio) in 2010. To ensure that the HFF remained solvent, the government made a capital injection of ISK 33 billion (2.1% of 2010 GDP) at the end of 2010. The European Surveillance Authority recently approved this state ..." ===Aftermath (2012–2013)=== {{Update|section|date=August 2014}} By mid-2012 Iceland was regarded as one of Europe's recovery success stories. It has had two years of economic growth. Unemployment was down to 6.3% and Iceland was attracting immigrants to fill jobs. Currency devaluation effectively reduced wages by 50% making exports more competitive and imports more expensive. Ten-year government bonds were issued below 6%, lower than some of the [[PIGS (economics)|PIIGS]] nations in the EU (Portugal, Italy, Ireland, Greece, and Spain). Tryggvi Thor Herbertsson, a member of parliament, noted that adjustments via currency devaluations are less painful than government labor policies and negotiations. Nevertheless, while EU fervor has cooled the government continued to pursue membership.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304203604577396171007652042?mod=ITP_pageone_0|title=In European Crisis, Iceland Emerges as an Island of Recovery|author=Forelle, Charles|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=19 May 2012}} Iceland [[2013 Icelandic parliamentary election|elected]] a [[Cabinet of Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson|new government]] in April 2013, which as one of their top priorities wanted to negotiate a debt [[Haircut (finance)|haircut]] towards foreign creditors of the three failed Icelandic banks now in receivership, as part of a deal to lift the long enforced (since November 2008) [[capital control]]s.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/298407e8-b19a-11e2-b324-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2eKmrZdHa|title=Iceland's creditors braced for losses|newspaper=Financial Times|date=2 May 2013|accessdate=9 September 2013}} The current capital controls ban a swap/exchange of ISK denominated assets to foreign currency, and so by effect has trapped repayment of ISK denominated assets to the creditors – which in theory mean they should be interested to accept a haircut in return for getting the capital controls lifted.{{Cite web|url=http://uti.is/2013/07/aspects-of-capital-controls-in-iceland-and-cyprus-and-the-long-time-damaging-effect/|title=Sigrún Davíðsdóttir's Icelog|publisher=|date=23 July 2013|accessdate=9 September 2013}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-04-30/iceland-lacks-currency-for-easy-exit-of-krona-creditors-1-.html|title=Iceland Lacks Currency for Easy Exit of Krona Creditors|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=30 April 2013|accessdate=9 September 2013}} The Icelandic government intent somehow to route the saved money from the negotiated debt haircut for creditors into a national household debt relief fund, enabling a 20% debt relief for all household mortgages. In July 2013, Standard & Poors recommended Iceland to drop the debt relief initiative, as it would only result in increased debt for the government – making it even more difficult to lend at credit markets, and it was forecasted also to ignite high inflation along with an economic recession equal to a GDP detraction of 10%.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/20fa6168-f5fa-11e2-a55d-00144feabdc0.html?siteedition=intl#axzz2eKmrZdHa|title=S&P warns Iceland over debt write-off plan|newspaper=Financial Times|date=26 July 2013|accessdate=9 September 2013}} The government has nevertheless appointed a taskforce to present proposals on how best to achieve the government's goal about implementing a combined capital control abolition and debt relief for households, with a reporting deadline in October 2013.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-08-21/iceland-keeps-western-europe-s-highest-rate-as-inflation-slows.html|title=Iceland Keeps Western Europe's Highest Rate as Krona Stable|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=21 August 2013|accessdate=9 September 2013}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/iceland-premier-says-no-date-to-lift-controls-1b~cNwqVTO6wEvCKoF6rww.html|title=Iceland Premier Says No Date to Lift Controls (video interview)|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=20 September 2013|accessdate=20 September 2013}} Capital controls were eventually ended in March 2017.BBC News, '[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-39248677 Iceland to end capital controls from 2008 financial crisis]' (12 March 2017).
